newsitem.title: TANZANIA: Tanzanian coffee traders hit by new export taxes.
newsitem.headline: Tanzanian coffee traders hit by new export taxes.

text.p: New taxes announced in Tanzania's 1996/97 budget have imposed additional expenses on local coffee traders already hit by declining earnings caused by a fall in production this season, traders said.
They said on Friday the new charges included a 1.2 percent stamp duty on exports and a 2.0 percent export tax.
The effect of these taxes will be retroactive for exporters, since they are applied according to the shipping date and take no account of the contract date, they said.
"One of the setbacks we are facing at the moment is the sudden reintroduction of stamp duty on exports plus an export tax," said a trader.
"This is one of the things that has really angered us because we are working on futures contracts basis," he added.
Total production in Tanzania in 1996/97 is forecast to decline to between 41,000 and 43,000 tonnes from 53,000 tonnes in 1995/96 and a peak of 68,000 tonnes in 1984/85.
Commenting on the taxes, Swiss-based trader Edm. Schluter & Co Ltd said this week "For coffee already bought and awaiting shipment, the additional burden of the taxation landed on the shipper."
Schluter added "It is to be hoped that changes in taxes and even tax rates in future will be discussed with the industry in advance." --Nairobi Newsroom ++254-2 330-261
